title: How to complete a Take Care Talk activity
steps: Conducted by a manager or team member at the start of the team Huddle in the work area.
Discuss 1:1 with team members if a Huddle cannot be conducted.
Encourage open conversation with team members using the discussion points below.
Feel free to adjust this message to a style that suits you and your team.
If this Take Care Talk is being completed as part of a safety activity, please record completion via the H&S Quicklinks page or scan the QR code.
examples: A mother breastfeeding in a fitting room.
A mother expressing milk on the shop floor.
A customer complains about seeing a mother breastfeeding; you advise them that this is a women's right under Australian Federal Law.
bestPractice: Seek help from your Store Manager if you are unsure.
caveats: K hubs do not have planograms; however this merchandising guidance still applies.
K hubs to follow the merchandising guidance described in point 7 above.
constraints: In Australian Federal Law, breastfeeding is a right, not a privilege.
Under the federal Sex Discrimination Act 1984 it is illegal in Australia to discriminate against a person either directly or indirectly on the grounds of breastfeeding.
This means, a woman has the right to breastfeed, or express milk, anywhere she chooses. This includes our stores.
No one should ever be asked by a team member to cover themselves or stop breastfeeding or expressing anywhere in our stores. This includes in fitting rooms or on the shop floor.
troubleshooting: If you receive a complaint from a customer you may advise them that this is a women's right under Australian Federal Law. If you are uncomfortable, unsure, or if the complaint escalates seek help from your Store Manager.
